channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Fires a Ballistic Missile, in a Further Challenge to Trump
item.media:description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, with two scientists — Ri Hong-sop, second from left, and Hong Sung-mu, right — in Pyongyang in September.
item.description: The missile flew higher than previous launches, and came despite President Trump’s warnings to the North.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER, CHOE SANG-HUN and HELENE COOPER

item.title: War Criminal Dies After Apparently Drinking Poison in Court
item.media:description: Former Croat leaders in the court in The Hague, before an appeals judgment in the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Robin Van Lonkhuijsen
item.description: At a tribunal considering appeals by six Croats convicted over actions in Bosnia, a former general drank from a vial after his sentence was upheld.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

item.title: In Eastern Europe, Populism Lives, Widening a Split in the E.U.
item.media:description: Far-right nationalists marched through Warsaw on Nov. 11 during Independence Day celebrations.
item.description: The populist wave that threatened to engulf Western Europe has largely stalled, but varied forms of populism in the east still threaten to infect the bloc.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In China, Fears That New Anticorruption Agency Will Be Above the Law
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping at the Communist Party congress in October. A proposed anticorruption watchdog has been criticized by China’s usually restrained lawyers and law professors.
item.description: Mainstream lawyers and law professors in China are taking a risk in speaking out against a move that they say would violate the country’s Constitution.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)

item.title: Australian State Passes Assisted Dying Law
item.media:description: An assisted dying bill was ratified by the state of Victoria on Wednesday, making it Australia’s first to legalize euthanasia.
item.description: After two and half years of debate and despite opposition from many doctors, the state of Victoria legalized voluntary euthanasia for some terminally ill patients.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Royal Engagement Seen as Symbol of Change, With Asterisks
item.media:description: Britain’s Prince Harry and Meghan Markle posed for photographers on the grounds of Kensington Palace in London, on Monday.
item.description: Some media commentators warned that the powerful symbolism did not diminish structural racism across Britain.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Charges Cast Spotlight on Singapore’s Strict Rules on Public Gatherings
item.media:description: Jolovan Wham, a civil activist in Singapore, was accused of organizing three small gatherings without police permission there in the past year.
item.description: Jolovan Wham held small gatherings, including one featuring the Hong Kong protest leader Joshua Wong by video, that resulted in charges by the police.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Reza Zarrab, Turk at Center of Iran Sanctions Case, Is Helping Prosecution
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab, a Turkish-Iranian businessman accused of conspiracy to violate United States sanctions against Iran, has been cooperating with the American authorities, a prosecutor said on Tuesday.
item.description: The gold trader, arrested in 2016, pleaded guilty in a case that has strained relations between the United States and Turkey.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Philippines Killed Communist Rebels Near Manila, Military Says
item.media:description: Fighters for the New People’s Army, a communist force, marking its 48th anniversary in April. The Philippine insurgency is one of the longest-running in Asia.
item.description: The fighting came on the same day that the government closed the door on peace talks.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: India’s Punishment for Plant-Eating Donkeys: Jail Time
item.media:description: In a photograph taken from an NDTV video, donkeys were shown leaving the jail in Orai, India, on Monday.
item.description: Eight of the animals were jailed for four days in Orai, India, as part of a cleanup campaign. Their crime: devouring expensive saplings.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Senate, North Korea, Uber: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Why German Markets Aren’t Worried About Angela Merkel. Yet.
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin on Nov. 20 after failed coalition talks. Investors have taken the political uncertainty in stride because of the strength of the German and European economies.
item.description: A strong economy and faith in Germany’s political system soothe investors. But the country’s prosperity may mask challenges down the road.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Canada Offers $85 Million to Victims of Its ‘Gay Purge,’ as Trudeau Apologizes
item.media:description: Prime Minister of Canada Justin Trudeau making a formal apology to individuals harmed by the so-called “gay purge” in Canada.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau apologized for Canada’s discrimination against gays and lesbians who were forced out of the military and public service.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Saudi Arabia Releases Senior Prince Arrested in Anti-Corruption Purge
item.media:description: Prince Mutaib bin Abdullah, right, who has been released from detention, with Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, left, and Saud bin Nayef in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in 2012.
item.description: The kingdom released Prince Mutaib bin Abdullah, the former head of the National Guard, a sign it is moving to resolve corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: OPEC Leader Cites ‘New Optimism’ With Oil Prices on the Rise
item.media:description: A Saudi Aramco oil complex in eastern Saudi Arabia. Higher prices could strain a Saudi agreement with Russia to hold down production.
item.description: With a 20 percent price surge in less than three months, members of the oil cartel must decide whether to extend production cuts.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: As Kenyatta is Inaugurated, Kenyans Are Feeling Economic Pain
item.media:description: A market in central Kisumu, Kenya, last month.
item.description: Kenya’s protracted presidential election badly hit the economy, affecting people across the social spectrum.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: Hawaii Brings Back a Cold War-Era Nuclear Warning System
item.media:description: Part of the coast in Oahu. Hawaii is testing a nuclear warning siren that will alert people to seek shelter in the face of an imminent attack.
item.description: Monthly tests are the latest in similar readiness steps by Hawaii amid renewed tensions between the United States and North Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Ireland Avoids Snap Election, but Its Leader Is Weakened
item.media:description: Prime Minister Leo Varadkar at his party’s conference in Ballyconnell, Ireland, this month.
item.description: The resignation of the deputy prime minister kept the government intact, but the crisis left Dublin vulnerable before talks on the future of its border with Britain.
item.dc:creator: ED O’LOUGHLIN

item.title: Facebook and Twitter Promise to Aid Inquiry on Russian Brexit Meddling
item.media:description: Facebook said it had been contacted by the British election regulator about Russian activity during the Brexit campaign, and would share its response with lawmakers.
item.description: British lawmakers are investigating whether Moscow influenced the 2016 referendum. The social media giants have promised information within weeks.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: North Korea Says It’s Now a Nuclear State. Could That Mean It’s Ready to Talk?
item.media:description: State television in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, announcing the country’s latest missile launch on Wednesday. The North said it had “finally realized the great historic cause of completing the state nuclear force.”
item.description: The North’s claims about its latest missile test raise the question of whether a deal to freeze its arsenal could be a possibility.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Bangkok Journal: Lurking in Toilets, Swimming the Streets: Snakes of Bangkok Move In
item.media:description: Firefighters restraining a rescued python at a fire station in Bangkok last week. One of the main jobs of the city’s Fire and Rescue Department is removing snakes from homes.
item.media:credit: Amanda Mustard for The New York Times
item.description: The Thai capital has always been rich in reptiles, but wet weather and urban growth are creating more snake-on-human encounters of an unpleasant kind.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and RYN JIRENUWAT

item.title: An Iranian Wrestler Throws His Match to Avoid an Israeli
item.media:description: At the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro in 2016, the Iranian wrestler Alireza Karimi-Machiani, right, lost to the American J’Den Cox.
item.description: The athlete was cruising against an inferior Russian until his coach shouted “Lose!” after learning who his next opponent would be.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: German Mayor Who Welcomed Refugees Is Stabbed by Angry Resident
item.media:description: Andreas Hollstein, mayor of Altena, Germany, on Tuesday, the day after he was attacked. “I will continue to work for people. For refugees and for the weaker members of society,” he said.
item.media:credit: Oliver Berg/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Andreas Hollstein, who won plaudits for taking in extra asylum seekers, was wounded in the neck, but he vowed not to alter his policy of openness.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: North Korea Could Have Nuclear ICBM Next Year, South Says
item.media:description: An image said to show North Korea’s most recent missile launch, of an intermediate-range Hwasong-12 in September.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: A South Korean official said his government was closely monitoring recent missile-related activities in the North for a possible resumption of weapons tests.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: In Myanmar, Pope Francis Calls for Peace Without Saying ‘Rohingya’
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving in Naypyidaw, Myanmar’s capital, on Tuesday. In a speech, he gave carefully worded remarks that sought to depict religious differences as a source of enrichment.
item.media:credit: Vatican press office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Rights advocates had hoped the pope would specifically denounce the military’s campaign of violence against the Muslim ethnic group.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Muay Thai Runs in the Family
item.description: An experienced Muay Thai teacher is training his 16 children in the martial art to keep them off the streets and to help pay for their education.

item.title: Japan’s Toray, a Major Supply Chain Link, Says It Falsified Data
item.media:description: The president of Toray Industries, Akihiro Nikkaku, left, and other company executives at a news conference in Tokyo on Tuesday. Toray said it had found 149 instances in which a subsidiary altered data to appear to meet manufacturing standards.
item.description: The company joins a growing number of firms that have admitted providing fake quality reports, dinging the Japanese reputation for quality.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Bali Volcano Eruption Strands Thousands of Travelers
item.media:description: Visitors were in limbo on Tuesday, waiting for a way out, at Ngurah Rai International Airport in Denpasar, Bali.
item.description: Tremors and ash from Mount Agung force evacuations and keep the Indonesian island’s international airport shut down.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Chinese General Being Investigated for Bribery Kills Himself
item.media:description: Zhang Yang, then head of the General Political Department of the People’s Liberation Army, in Beijing in 2014.
item.description: State media moved quickly to vilify Gen. Zhang Yang, who committed suicide as he was being investigated in Xi Jinping’s crackdown on corruption.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: China Sentences Taiwanese Human Rights Activist in Subversion Case
item.media:description: Lee Ming-cheh appearing in court in Yueyang, China, in September. He was accused of trying to foment a revolution.
item.media:credit: Yueyang Intermediate People's Court, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Lee Ming-cheh was sentenced to five years in prison in the first case in which China has convicted a Taiwanese citizen of state subversion.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Mexico’s Finance Minister Says He’ll Run for President
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico, right, announcing the resignation on Monday of José Antonio Meade, the finance minister.
item.description: José Antonio Meade stepped down from his post and said he would run next year as the candidate of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Venezuela Appoints General to Tighten Grip on Oil Industry
item.media:description: Venezuela’s president has named Maj. Gen. Manuel Quevedo, right, to lead the state-owned energy company and the oil ministry.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Skeptics said the appointment at the state-owned oil company was part of a move by the president to consolidate control over the industry.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: News Analysis: Prince Harry Casts Aside Ghosts of Royal Marriages Past
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his fiancée, Meghan Markle, arrived for photographs in the Sunken Garden at Kensington Palace on Monday.
item.description: Harry, fifth in line to the throne, may never be king. But his mere choice of bride may give Britain a strong shove into the future.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: ‘It Was a Blood Bath’: Freight Trains Kill 110 Reindeer in Norway
item.media:description: An image from a video taken on Saturday shows a train driving past dead reindeer near Mosjoen in northern Norway. More than 100 reindeer were killed by trains in the area in the past week.
item.media:credit: John Erling Utsi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Animal advocacy groups urge speed limits, new fencing and digital tracking to prevent more accidents.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Mick Mulvaney, Elizabeth Warren, Meghan Markle: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Protest Targeting Opposition Lawmakers Stirs Outrage in Poland
item.media:description: Prime Minister Beata Szydlo of Poland, bottom center, during a parliamentary debate on a Supreme Court bill in Warsaw this year.
item.description: Pictures of Polish opposition lawmakers shown on symbolic gallows have stirred memories of the intolerant politics of Poland’s not-so-distant past.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: She Accused a Moroccan Pop Star of Rape. Online, She Was Vilified.
item.media:description: The Moroccan pop star Saad Lamjarred, center. He is awaiting trial on rape charges in France, where his 21-year-old accuser has gone into hiding after receiving threats from his fans.
item.description: A young Frenchwoman has made an internet plea to clear her name and counter threats, opening a debate about sexual assault in the Arab world.
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI

item.title: Health of Bahrain’s Top Shiite Cleric Worsens
item.media:description: Ayatollah Sheikh Isa Qassim, center, at a protest at a mosque in the capital of Bahrain, Manama, in 2014.
item.description: Ayatollah Sheikh Isa Qassim, regarded as the spiritual voice of Bahrain’s Shiite majority, risks deportation if he leaves his home for treatment.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: British Royal Weddings and the Barriers That Fell With Them
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle at Kensington Palace in London on Monday.
item.description: A look back at other weddings by members of the British monarchy highlights the scrutiny and occasional controversy that have surrounded the couples.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Prince Harry Used Princess Diana’s Diamonds in Engagement Ring
item.media:description: Prince Harry of Britain with his fiancée, Meghan Markle, as she showed off her engagement ring in the Sunken Garden at Kensington Palace in west London on Monday.
item.description: The diamonds flank a larger central stone from Botswana, where he and his fiancée, Meghan Markle, went on vacation early in their relationship.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Two Former Mugabe Allies Are Held Without Bail in Zimbabwe
item.media:description: Ignatius Chombo, center left, and Kudzanai Chipanga — former allies of Zimbabwe’s ousted president — being led to a prison truck at the magistrates court in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Saturday.
item.description: Their cases are being closely watched for signs about how the new government will deal with former allies of the ousted president.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO

item.title: How Prince Harry Proposed to Meghan Markle
item.description: Prince Harry and his fiancée, Meghan Markle, an American actress and humanitarian, describe how they became engaged. Yes, he got down on one knee.

item.title: Glyphosate, Top-Selling Weed Killer, Wins E.U. Approval for 5 Years
item.media:description: Edward Ford on his farm in Brentwood, England, where he relies on the weed killer glyphosate.
item.description: The decision to reauthorize use of the world’s best-selling herbicide for an abbreviated period was made amid opposition from several of the union’s member states, including France and Italy.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: The Breakdown: How to Fix Australia’s Paralyzed Parliament
item.media:description: Skye Kakoschke-Moore, an Australian-British citizen, announced her resignation from the Senate on Wednesday as the leader of her party, Nick Xenophon, looked on.
item.description: Nine lawmakers were forced to resign because they are dual citizens. Scholars have a few ideas about how to change that.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: After Tumultuous Week, Germany’s Politics Look to the Familiar
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel with leaders of her Christian Democratic Union party during a meeting in Berlin on Monday.
item.description: Leaders of the German chancellor’s conservative party say a coalition with the Social Democrats would provide more stability than a minority government.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Vietnamese Blogger Gets 7 Years in Jail for Reporting on Toxic Spill
item.media:description: Nguyen Van Hoa at his trial in Ha Tinh, Vietnam, on Monday. He was convicted of spreading anti-state propaganda for producing videos and writing about protests over an environmental disaster.
item.media:credit: Cong Tuong/Vietnam News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Nguyen Van Hoa was convicted of spreading information about the discharge that killed marine life and sickened people along a 120-mile stretch of coastline.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Tokyo Journal: Tokyo, Once a Cigarette Haven, Could Finally Kick Out the Smokers
item.media:description: Tokyo is considering a ban on smoking indoors in most public places. In this intensely rule-abiding country, some say changing smoking rules would test the resolve of many.
item.media:credit: Tomohiro Ohsumi for The New York Times
item.description: A no-smoking ordinance being considered by the city raises the question of whether the famously rule-abiding Japanese would obey it.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Pope Francis Arrives in a Myanmar Tarnished by Rohingya Crackdown
item.media:description: Pope Francis after his arrival on Monday at the airport in Yangon, Myanmar.
item.description: The pope met with the top commander of the military, which has led a campaign to drive Rohingya Muslims out. He will meet Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
